Proud to be part of a diverse committee on E&C to bring a voice to our communities of color and those in low-income areas. As a United For Climate Action Task Force, we are combining the strength of the Tri-Caucus to push bills to address the inequalities.
Congress will also continue to push forward bills, like HR 9, the #ClimateActionNow bill, that will put climate change at the forefront of our agenda.

As a task force, we will continue to lead letters like our most recent one to the Appropriations Committee leadership urging them to reject President Trump’s 2020 budget proposal to slash funding for the EPA and to instead increase funding by at least 10 percent.

At a time when it feels like all of our core environmental protections are under attack, we must continue our work in calling out this administration’s disastrous policies, push bills that address our communities’ priorities and provide a voice for the voiceless.

As a member of @EnergyCommerce, we will continue to hold hearings and introduce legislation that will protect our public health. We also need to continue to fight back on the administration's environmental protection rollbacks that disproportionately harm communities of color.
That’s why it was so important to me that @EnergyCommerce held a hearing last week on rollbacks on cleaner car standards that undermine our efforts to clean up the air in our communities.
My district is also surrounded by interstate highways and the Port of Los Angeles where ships, trucks and other heavy-duty vehicles burn fossil fuels & create air pollution.

In my district, children share their backyards and playgrounds with oil wells. That’s why I introduced the No Drilling in Our Backyards Act, which would ensure that oil and gas drilling occurs at least 1,500 feet away from homes, businesses, schools & other protected areas.
As one of the most polluted districts in the country, the communities that I represent are experiencing the impacts of climate change first and worst.

While California is known for its beautiful landscape, residents of Los Angeles and across the state suffer from some of the worst air quality in the country largely attributed to fossil fuel emissions.
